0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• when pneumococcal 13-valent vaccine is also indicated, that vaccine should be given first
  • Pneumococcal vaccination, 23-Valent vaccine: (50 years or older) administer 1 dose IM/SUBQ (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pneumococcal vaccination, 23-Valent vaccine: (Revaccination) Administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM/SUBQ; routine revaccination of immunocompetent persons is not recommended

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• all recommended pneumococcal 13-valent vaccine doses should be administered prior to pneumococcal 23 valent vaccine, if possible; minimum age for vaccination is 2 years
  • Pneumococcal vaccination, 23-Valent vaccine: (2 years or older at increased risk) Administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM/SUBQ

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: anaphylactic/anaphylactoid or severe allergic reaction to any component of the pneumococcal vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness, moderate or severe; defer vaccination
  • American Indians or Alaskan natives; routine vaccination not recommended; may vaccinate if reside in a region with increased risk of invasive disease
  • antibiotic prophylaxis against pneumococcal infection; vaccine does not replace the need for penicillin or other antibiotic prophylaxis
  • cardiovascular function, severely compromised; a systemic reaction would pose a significant risk
  • cerebrospinal fluid leakage, chronic, resulting from congenital lesions, skull fractures, or neurosurgical procedures; vaccine may not be effective in preventing pneumococcal meningitis
  • concurrent administration of live zoster vaccine (Zostavax(R)); reduced immune response to zoster vaccine has been reported; consider administrating the 2 vaccines at least 4 weeks apart
  • immunocompromised, including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy; expected antibody response may not be obtained
  • pulmonary function, severely compromised; a systemic reaction would pose a significant risk
  • report adverse reactions to VAERS at 1-800-822-7967 or at www.vaers.hhs.gov

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (16.4% to 34.5%), Injection site edema, Injection site induration, Injection site pain, Injection site reaction
  • Musculoskeletal:Myalgia (11.9% to 17.3%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia, Headache (17.6% to 18.1%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Hemolytic anemia, Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction, Serum sickness due to drug
  • Neurologic:Guillain-Barr syndrome
  • Other:Angioedema, Fever, Greater than 102 degrees F

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Pneumococcal capsular polysaccharide antigens induce type-specific antibodies that enhance opsonization, phagocytosis, and killing of pneumococci by leukocytes and other phagocytic cells .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    • administer subQ or IM; do not give IV or intradermally; do not mix with other vaccines
    • 23-valent pneumococcal vaccine may be administered at the same time as influenza vaccine by separate injection in the other arm.
  • Intramuscular
    preferred injection site is in the deltoid muscle or lateral mid-thigh

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• If patient is taking penicillin as prophylaxis against pneumococcal infection, advise patient to continue penicillin therapy after vaccination, unless otherwise directed by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause fever or soreness, erythema, swelling, or induration at injection site.
  • Advise patient to report angioedema (deep swelling around eyes and lips and sometimes hands and feet) or signs/symptoms of hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia.
